entry.title: Subscription Management for Software (5SW)
entry.content:
In today’s software-driven business environment, subscription-based models are increasingly the norm. Managing subscriptions, entitlements, usage, billing  and revenue recognition can become complex without a robust system in place. SAP addresses this challenge with an integrated end-to-end process across SAP Cloud ERP, SAP Subscription Billing, and SAP Entitlement Management. This solution simplifies subscription management while enabling automation and comprehensive insights into software usage and revenue.

With 2508 release SAP has provided an end-2-end Best Practice content for Software and SaaS use cases. The goal of this Best Practice is to significantly reduce time-to-value by providing clear setup instructions for common processes along the end-2-end value chain. The Best Practice content is provided via the new scope item 5SW (link to scope item in the Process Navigator).

 

What does Scope Item 5SW cover?

This scope item enables a seamless process for the full lifecycle of software subscriptions. From subscription modeling and pricing to fulfillment, billing, and revenue recognition, the integration ensures all steps are connected:

  • Subscription Modeling & Pricing: Define software subscription products, base and add-on licenses, and pricing models.
  • Sales & Fulfillment: Sell subscriptions through solution orders in SAP Cloud ERP and manage provisioning in SAP Entitlement Management.
  • License & Usage Management: Track entitlements, license consumption, and software usage to ensure compliance and optimize revenue.
  • Billing & Revenue Recognition: Automate billing for recurring, one-time, and usage-based charges, and ensure accurate revenue recognition.
  • End-of-Life Processes: Decommission licenses and tenants at the end of subscription contracts efficiently.

This scope item consolidates several existing capabilities, including Subscription Management with Sales Billing, corresponding capabilities of Solution Order Management, and Event-Based Revenue Recognition, Subscription Billing, extended with SAP Entitlement Management functionalities.

Key Process Flow

Process Flow

  1. Creation or Update of the Solution Order
    The Solution Order Specialist initiates the process by creating a new Solution Order or updating an existing one. This serves as the foundation for all subsequent subscription and billing activities.
  2. Automatic Subscription Creation in SAP Subscription Billing
    If the Solution Order includes a subscription item, a corresponding subscription is automatically created in SAP Subscription Billing with a pending status. This ensures that the subscription lifecycle is immediately tracked and initialized.
  3. Entitlement Assignment and Provisioning
    In SAP Entitlement Management, entitlements can be added to the subscription to define the customer’s access rights. Once entitlements are assigned, tenant and license provisioning are triggered to enable the actual usage.
  4. Subscription Finalization and Activation
    After entitlement configuration and provisioning, the subscription is finalized and activated. This marks the transition from setup to operational use.
  5. Automatic Creation of Provider Contract and Billing Plan
    With the subscription activated, SAP Cloud ERP automatically generates the Provider Contract and the associated billing plan. These define the contractual framework and scheduling for invoicing.
  6. Revenue Recognition
    Based on the activated subscription and billing data, Revenue Recognition can be monitored in the SAP Cloud ERP system.

 

  1. Detection of Billing Cycle End
    Once the end of the billing cycle is detected, the process for capturing license usage begins. In SAP Entitlement Management, both software consumption and actual license utilization are recorded.
  2. Transfer and Rating of Usage Data
    The recorded usage data is automatically sent to SAP Subscription Billing. There, it is rated according to the predefined price models and tariff rules.
  3. Automatic Billing in SAP Subscription Billing
    Based on the consumed quantity and the billing cycle, SAP Subscription Billing automatically generates bills. This eliminates manual effort and ensures consistent and rule-based billing.
  4. Creation of Billing Document Request (BDR)
    The generated bills are transferred to SAP Cloud ERP, where a Billing Document Request (BDR) is created. This serves as the foundation for further processing in the ERP system.
  5. Generation of Billing Documents
    Using the BDR, the final Billing Documents are created in SAP Cloud ERP. They contain all relevant billing information and can be used for financial posting and customer communication.
  6. Event-Based Revenue Recognition
    Finally, event-based Revenue Recognition is executed. This ensures that revenue is posted in compliance with accounting standards, enabling accurate financial reporting.

  1. Decommissioning of Tenants and Licenses
    Once the subscription contract reaches its end, the associated tenants and licenses can be properly decommissioned. This ensures that access is revoked, resources are released, and the offboarding process is completed in a controlled manner.

 

Business Benefits

Implementing this integrated scope item delivers significant advantages:

  • End-to-End Automation: Streamline modelling, selling, fulfillment, and billing of software subscriptions.
  • Flexible License Management: Use generic license templates for multiple applications, tenant types, and metrics.
  • Efficient Provisioning & Updates: Automate updates, add-ons, and decommissioning of licenses and tenants.
  • Usage Insights: Monitor adoption, detect low, and prevent revenue leakage from overuse.
  • Flexible Billing Models: Support recurring, one-time, and usage-based billing.
  • Integrated Revenue Recognition: Ensure compliance and accuracy in multi-license scenarios.

Conclusion

By combining SAP Cloud ERP, SAP Subscription Billing, and SAP Entitlement Management, businesses can achieve a fully integrated, automated subscription management process to explicitly cover common requirements of software & SaaS use cases. This approach not only reduces operational complexity but also enhances visibility into software usage, adoption, and revenue—empowering companies to maximize value from their subscription offerings.

For further information or any questions, you can reach out to me:

Faruk Gedik (Business Process Consultant), faruk.gedik@sap.com

and I will be happy to assist you.

entry.title: A Practical Guide to Extending Standard Billing Forms in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
One of the most frequent topics customers seek guidance on is how they can tailor their business documents to reflect their unique brand and operational needs. While the standard forms we deliver are a fantastic starting point, your billing document is a key touchpoint with your customers, and it needs to be just right.

Today, I’m going to walk you through a practical, step-by-step guide on how to extend the standard billing document form template to meet some of the most common business requirements. We'll cover adding your company logo, including standard and custom fields, adding static text, and even generating multiple copies such as customer copy or archive copy of a single invoice.

Let’s get started!

The Core Tools of the Trade

Before we dive into the details, let's familiarize ourselves with the key applications and tools we will be using in the SAP Fiori launchpad:

1. Maintain Form Templates App: This is your central hub for managing all form templates. Here, you can copy standard templates, download the layout files, upload your modified versions, and activate them.
2. Custom Fields App: A powerful application that allows you to create your own business-specific fields and make them available in various business contexts, including form templates.
3. Output Parameter Determination App: After you have a beautiful new form, this app is where you define the business rules that tell the system when to use it (e.g., for a specific company code, sales organization, or customer).

Adobe LiveCycle Designer: This is the design tool used to edit the visual layout of the form. You will need to have it installed on your local machine (available via app Install Additional Software).


Step 1: Create Your Custom Form Template

SAP delivers default form templates that you can copy to create your own custom form templates

1. Open the Maintain Form Templates app, and navigate to the Predelivered Templates tab..
2. Search for SDBIL_CI_STANDARD* to find the standard templates for customer invoices.You will see localized versions like “SDBIL_CI_STANDARD_US” or “SDBIL_CI_STANDARD_DE”.
3. Select the standard template that best fits your region and select Copy.
4. Give your new template a name. For example: `YY1_MYCORP_BILLING_FORM_US`.
5. Click OK.


Step 2: Download the Layout and Make Basic Changes

Now that you have your custom copy, let's download the layout file and add some fundamental customizations.

1. On the Custom Templates tab, search for your new template.

2. Open the form template, then select Download.

3 Save and extract the zip archive. The archive contains the form template as an XDP file, data provider information in XSD format, and optionally, the form template master, also as an XDP file.

You are now in the design environment. On the left, you'll see the `Hierarchy` and `Data View` tabs. The `Data View` shows all the data fields available from the system, while the `Hierarchy` shows the structure of the form itself.


Common Requirement: Adding a Company Logo

The recommended way to manage logos in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition with the Manage Logos app. You upload your logo there and it gets a unique name. The form can then pull it dynamically.

1. Open the XDP file via Adobe LiveCycle Designer

2. In LiveCycle Designer, find the placeholder for the logo (it's often an Image Field object at the top).
3. Select the Image Field and go to the Object  palette.
4. Ensure the Embed Image Data option is unchecked.
5. Go to the Binding palette. You should see a binding reference like `$record.Form_Header.Logo.URL`. This tells the form to fetch the logo URL provided by the system. By using the Manage Logos app and this binding will work automatically.


Common Requirement: Adding Static Text (e.g., Terms & Conditions)

1. In the Hierarchy view, find the content area where you want to add the text (e.g., `contentArea`).
2. Drag a Text object from the Object Library onto your form's design view.
3. Double-click the new text object and type or paste your terms and conditions.
4. In the Layout palette, make sure the Expand to Fit options are checked so the text block can grow as needed.

Step 3: Extending the Form with Custom Fields

This is where the real power of extensibility shines. Let's say you need to add a "Project Manager" name to your billing documents, a field that doesn't exist in the standard system.

Part A: Create the Custom Field in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

1. Open the Custom Fields app.
2. Click the +icon to create a new field.
3. Select the Select the business context Sales: Billing Document. This is crucial as it determines where the field can be used.
4. Provide a label for your field (e.g., “Project Manager”). Based on the label, the system suggests an identifier, for example, “YY1_ProjectManager
5. Choose a Type, such as `Text`, and set the length.
6. Navigate to the Form Templates tab. Find the data source and check the Enable Usage box.
7. (Recommended) Navigate to the User Interfaces tab. Enable the field for `Manage Billing Documents` and `Create Billing Documents` (business context - Sales: Billing Due List) so you can see and edit it directly in the Fiori apps.
8. Save and Publish your field. This process can take a few minutes.


Part B: Update the Form Data Source and Layout

1. Go back to the Maintain Form Templates app.
2. Open your custom template (`YY1_MYCORP_BILLING_FORM_US`).
3. Download the form template again. This is a critical step! Downloading the template again ensures the XDP 's schema is updated with the new custom field you just published.
4. Open the new XDP file in Adobe LiveCycle Designer.
5. Go to the Data View tab. Expand the nodes to find your new field, YY1_ProjectManager.

6.Drag your new field from the `Data View` and drop it onto the form canvas where you want it to appear. A caption and a text field will be created automatically.
7. Style and position the new field to match the rest of your form.

Step 4: Upload and Activate Your Masterpiece

Once you are happy with all your changes, it's time to upload the form back into the system.

1. Save your XDP file in Adobe LiveCycle Designer.

2. Return to the Maintain Form Templates app in the SAP Fiori launchpad.

3. On the Custom Templates tab, choose New.

4. In the Create Form Template window, enter the form template name.

5. To specify the location of the custom template XDP, choose Browse.

6. From the Data Provider dropdown list, select FDP_V3_BD_STANDARD_SRV.

7. To generate the custom template, choose OK.

8. Finally, assign the form to a Business Context using configuration activity: Assign Form Templates. Your form is now live and ready to be used.

Step 5: Define When to Use Your New Form

The last step is to tell the system the business rules for when to use your new form. This is done in the Output Parameter Determination app.

1. Open the app and select Billing Document from the Show Rules for dropdown.
2. Select the Form Template determination step.
3. In edit mode, create a new rule in the Decision Table. You can set conditions like: use `YY1_MYCORP_BILLING_FORM_US` IF `Company Code` is `1010`, or IF `Sales Organization` is `US01`.
4. Activate the new rule.

 

Common Requirement: Generate multiple output items – KBA 2757763 - How to print to multiple print queues or generate multiple output items.

Now, when a billing document is created that matches your conditions, the system will automatically use your beautifully customized form template.

Bonus tip on optimized handling of large data files :

In certain business processes, the form data XML can get too large and form rendering is rejected from the Adobe Document Services.
In such cases, you can try the following options to reduce the size of the form data XML:

• Use the 'Untag PDF' option in the 'Assign Form Templates' configuration activity.
Depending on your configuration environment, you do configuration activities in either the Manage Your Solution app or in SAP Central Business Configuration. To access the documentation for configuration activities, open the Actions menu and select 'Configuration Help' (for Manage Your Solution) or choose 'Open Documentation' in the documentation column (for Central Business Configuration).

• Use the 'Optimize data service' option in the 'Maintain Form Templates' app.
By default, during form rendering all data fields contained in the form data provider are sent to the Adobe Document Services for rendering. When enabling the newly introduced flag: Optimize data service the underlying template source will be statically analyzed. Only data fields that are directly used in a data binding by form elements will be transferred. This reduces the data transfer volume and improve the rendering performance.

Note that only data fields that are bound to an element in the form template will be detected and kept. Data fields that are only accessed via scripting are not supported. You can check existing data bindings by using the data view control in the Adobe LiveCycle Designer for SAP Solutions.

SAP recommends testing the output by generating a preview when enabling this feature.


Further Reading

For more in-depth information, please refer to these official resources:

* Setting Up Output Management - 1LQ Set Up Guide

* SAP Community : How to Bring Custom Fields to Billing Document Output (Video Tutorial)

* SAP Help Portal: Manage Your SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition -> Document and Output Management

* SAP Help Portal : Output Management for Sales Documents and Billing Process Documents

* KBA 2984817 - Form design in Adobe LiveCycle Designer


I hope this guide empowers you to take control of your form templates. Customizing your business documents is a fantastic way to improve communication with your customers and streamline your own internal processes.

Happy customizing!

entry.title: 资产负债表/损益表中的勾稽关系不平如何应对？
entry.content:
一.什么是勾稽关系？
勾稽关系指账簿和会计报表中有关数字之间存在的，可据以相互考察、核对的关系。这种关系是会计恒等式的核心，它确保了财务报表的内部一致性。每一项资产的增加都必须伴随负债或所有者权益的增加，或者是其他资产的减少。同样，每一项负债的增加，都必须伴随着资产的增加或者是所有者权益的减少。
这个关系帮助企业确保其记录的财务信息是完整和准确的，并且能够反映真实的财务状况。通过检查勾稽关系，财务人员可以验证资产负债表的正确性，发现可能的错误或遗漏。

二.资产负债表和损益表如何实现衔接？
按照会计标准，资产负债表和损益表主要通过“未分配利润”项目实现衔接关系。资产负债表中“未分配利润”的期末余额 - 资产负债表中“未分配利润”的期初余额 =损益表中当期“净利润”总额。

三.如何检查为何勾稽关系不平？
打开 “资产负债表/损益表 - 中国”应用，找到“未分配科目”（栏位）。执行以下检查：

 

 

1)检查制造费用科目（职能范围为“制造”的总账科目）的总和是否为 0。如果不为 0，则结转到 0。
查找受影响的订单/物料: 检查生产科目是否平衡的有效方法是按功能范围检查余额。

a) 打开应用日记账分录分析器。
b) 输入公司代码、会计年度和期间。
c) 仅在行中放置“功能范围”。通常，生产功能范围应为 YB20。如果 YB20 的余额为零，则表示生产科目应平衡。
d) 如果存在余额，您可以放出“订单标识”字段并清除其他字段。检查具有余额的确切订单。如果找到个别订单有余额，您可以单独分析这些订单来找到问题原因。

查找货币间的余额

a) 通常，活动类型重估仅能确保全球货币平衡。如果全球货币和公司代码货币不同，则可能存在以公司代码货币计的余额。
b) 还需要考虑的一点是，应在物料分类账关账后确保没有“未分配/未分摊”值。您可以通过物料价值流监控器应用检查相同的内容。
c) 如果维护手动活动价格，您需要使用正确的价格单位和正确的货币维护正确的手动活动价格。
d) 在编辑实际成本核算运行中，确保设置“再次处理”选项。
e) 要解决以全球货币计的未分配值，应在编辑实际成本核算运行的结算步骤中勾选“无库存覆盖范围检查”。

2)检查未分配科目中是否存在销售费用、管理费用和研发费用（职能范围为“销售/管理/研发”的总账科目）。如果存在，则余额总和应为 0。如果总和不为 0，则将其分配到 FSV 节点。

3)打开“管理全局层次结构”应用或者配置点 "定义会计报表版本"（ID:102669)，打开您为公司定义的资产负债表和损益表的财务报表版本，仔细检查是否存在任何不合理的配置。
例如，损益类科目是否分配到资产负债表中的 FSV 节点下或者对于一些总账科目，只选择了仅借方或仅贷方，但实际同时存在借方和贷方过账。例如下图中 D,C 两列都应该勾选，但客户只勾选了 D 列。

 

总体而言，一旦资产负债表/损益表中出现勾稽关系不平的问题，我们的财务工作者需要做大量细致的检查。
希望如上信息可以帮助到您。

Best regards,

Lola

entry.title: Articulation relationship of Balance Sheet/Income Statements is uneven
entry.content:
一.What is the Balancing Relationship?
The balancing relationship refers to the interconnections between numbers within accounting ledgers and financial statements that allow for mutual examination and verification. It forms the core of the accounting equation, which ensures the internal consistency of financial statements. In essence, whenever there is an increase in any asset, it must be matched by a corresponding increase in liabilities or owners' equity, or by a decrease in another asset. Similarly, every increase in liabilities must be mirrored by an increase in assets or a decrease in owners' equity.
This balancing act is crucial for companies to ensure that their recorded financial information is both complete and precise, accurately reflecting the true financial position. By regularly examining these relationships, financial personnel can verify the correctness of the balance sheet and identify potential errors or omissions.

二.Why is it Important?
The balancing relationship is more than just numbers on a page; it is a critical tool for maintaining the integrity of financial data. For businesses, it means that stakeholders can trust the information presented, which is essential for decision-making, compliance, and overall financial health. Mistakes in financial data can lead to poor strategic decisions, legal penalties, or damaged reputations.
In conclusion, understanding and maintaining the balancing relationship within financial statements is not merely about fulfilling accounting obligations—it is about fostering trust and transparency. As financial landscapes become more complex, mastering these fundamentals will continue to be vital for all companies striving for accuracy and integrity in their reporting.

三.How to Check Why the Balancing Relationship is Not Equilibrated?

Open the app "Balance Sheet/Income Statement" or app "Balance Sheet / Income Statement - China" and find the field Unassigned Accounts. Export these accounts under the tab Unassigned Accounts to spreadsheet (for example, Microsoft Excel), filter with “Functional Area”, and then do the following checks first:

1)Check whether the sum of manufacturing expense accounts (G/L accounts with functional area “manufacturing”) is 0. If it is not 0, carry forward to 0.
a)Open App Journal Entry Analyzer.
b)Input company code, fiscal year and period.
c)Only put "Functional Area" in Rows. Normally the production functional area should be YB20. If the balance for YB20 is zero, it means that the accounts for production should be balanced.
d)If there is balance, you can release the field "Order ID" and check for which exact order is with balance. Afterwards, you could make analysis on the specific order.

Balance between currencies

a)Normally the activity type revaluation will only ensure the global currency is balanced.
If you are using different currencies for global and company code currency, there might be balance in company code currency.
b)One more thing to consider is that you should make sure there is no "Not Distributed/Not Allocated" value after material ledger closing. You can check the same via app Material Value Flow Monitor.
c)If you maintain manual activity prices. You need to maintain the correct manual activity price with correct price unit and in the correct expected currency.
d)In Edit Actual Costing Run, make sure you set option "Process again".
e)To solve the Not Distributed value in global currency, you should tick "No stock coverage check" in Settlement step of Edit Actual Costing Run.

2)Check whether there are sales expenses, management expenses and R&D expenses (G/L accounts with functional areas “sales/management/R&D”) in the unassigned accounts. If there are, the sum of balance should be 0. If the sum is not 0, assign them to FSV nodes.

3)Open the app "Manage Global Hierarchies" or the or the configuration activity Define Financial Statement Versions（ID:102669) and open the financial statement version for Balance Sheet and Income Statement that you have defined for your company, double check whether there are any unreasonable configurations, for example, P&L accounts are assigned under FSV nodes in Balance Sheet; only Dr. or Cr. Indicator is selected for certain G/L accounts, but actually both debit and credit postings exist.

Hope the information could help you!

Best regards,

Lola

entry.title: Using Settlement Account for Non-Material Receivers in Production Order Settlement
entry.content:
This blog will introduce non-material settlement receiver features in  Event-Based Production Cost Posting (3F0)

Business Scenarios

For manufacturing orders in SAP Cloud ERP system, accounting journal entries associated with business transaction events -raw material consumptions, activity confirmations and goods receipts reflect manufacturing costing process in management accounting. The balances of orders are usually settled to materials as variance postings. However, sometimes, order settlement receivers may not be materials, rather they are cost centers, WBS elements or other orders. For example, orders may need to be settled to cost centers as research expenses.

Product Features

In configuration Event-Based Processing Key,  as in the screenshot below, in addition to Material, Cost center, WBS Element and Order are also supported.

In Non-Material Account Determination Rule, two methods are supported: By Original Account and By Settlement Account.(Please refer to official documentation Event-Based Cost Distribution (Non-MAT Receivers) for more details)

A settlement account needs to be maintained if settlement account option is chosen.

Process Illustrations

We will show the steps of creating a production order, maintain settlement rule, perform postings and settlements. A production order is being created and navigate to settlement rule to make a cost center as receiver.

Maintain the settlement rule to a cost center

After performing material good issues, activity confirmations. The order balance is always zero, as the costs are re-posted to cost centers.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

We can also view the order in Fiori app Display Document Flow, and it generates six documents, of which doc1,2,4,5 are trigged by goods issues, activity confirmations and overhead (as costing sheet is used in the demo) as expected for any other orders regardless of receivers in settlement rules.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

For the tagged doc 3 and 6 in above screenshot, they show the settlement postings from the order to the cost center. The two journal entries are shown below(for materials and activity type amount settlements respectively), the settlement G/L account maintained in Event-Based Processing Key is being used.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

The cost center report should show the postings under settlement account, which may need to be included in financial statement version to include the expenses in income statement report.

Summary

The above has illustrated the product features with regards to cost center as receiver in production order settlement using settlement account approach. Feel free the leave comments below and explore other blogs and content in the community.

entry.title: Production Order Settlement to WBS Elements
entry.content:
In the previous blog, Using Settlement Account for Non-Material Receivers in Production Order Settlement, we discussed and illustrated production order settlement to a cost center; however, the settlement account was a 2nd cost element, and it needed to be included in the financial report to reflect the expenses in income statement. What if we want to settle the costs to cost centers via primary cost elements. We can achieve this with the help of WBS elements as settlement receivers. We will illustrate this process below.

Firstly, a project is created.

Maintain the settlement rule of WBS as G/L Category. A primary cost element account is entered here. (This expense account needs to set up cost center as default account assignment in configuration or BAdI)

We create a production order without material (CO07)

Maintain order settlement rule as WBS element Category with previous created WBS element

After the activity confirmations have been performed on the production order. As can be seen below, the WBS element receives all the activity confirmation postings from the production order.

We perform Project settlement job and view the settlement document

 

A closer look at the accounting document generated from WBS settlement. The expense has been posted to the cost center.

Conclusion

Since production order settlement does not support G/L Account as receiver or settlement account as a primary cost element, WBS elements can be used to receive the postings from production orders first and then be settled to cost centers via a primary cost element account.
